docs.abstract: The outrage of Republican presidential candidates over a “war on religion” shouldn’t distract us from the real possibility of compromise on health care insurance and contraception.
docs.snippet: The outrage of Republican presidential candidates over a “war on religion” shouldn’t distract us from the real possibility of compromise on health care insurance and contraception.

docs.lead_paragraph: In my old neighborhood in a patch at the north end of Spokane, Washington, not only was John F. Kennedy a saint, but the family from which he came was viewed as the norm - that is, a brood of nine or more kids, each a year or so apart. Birth control in the mid-1960s was the rhythm method, and its failed efficacy was evident in the size of the clans. "The I-got-rhythm method," my dad called it.
docs.abstract: The outrage of Republican presidential candidates over a "war on religion" shouldn't distract us from the real possibility of compromise on health care insurance and contraception.
docs.snippet: The outrage of Republican presidential candidates over a "war on religion" shouldn't distract us from the real possibility of compromise on health care insurance and contraception.

headline.main: Drug Costs Pose Smaller Financial Burden Amid Generic Boom

docs.abstract: Americans are using more prescription drugs, but the financial burden of those drugs on families is falling, according to a new study. A big reason is the rise of generics.
docs.snippet: Americans are using more prescription drugs, but the financial burden of those drugs on families is falling, according to a new study. A big reason is the rise of generics.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks to greater use of generic drugs, the financial burden of prescription costs has become less of an issue for families in the United States, according to a new study by the RAND Corporation.

headline.main: Drug Costs Pose Smaller Financial Burden Amid Generic Boom

docs.abstract: Americans are using more prescription drugs, but the financial burden of those drugs on families is falling, according to a new study. A big reason is the rise of generics.

headline.main: Should Obama Have His Own Plan B?

docs.abstract: What the Obama administration should do about the controversy over contraception, health care and Catholic institutions.
docs.snippet: What the Obama administration should do about the controversy over contraception, health care and Catholic institutions.

byline.original: By DAVID BROOKS and GAIL COLLINS

docs.lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, I was kind of glad to discover that we have a disagreement about President Obama's decision to require Catholic hospitals and universities to cover contraceptives in their health insurance plans. Generally, when the topic turns to sex - gay marriage, abortion rights - we're pretty much on the same page. That makes for boring conversations.

docs.snippet: What the Obama administration should do about the controversy over contraception, health care and Catholic institutions.

headline.main: Washington Post Will Further Reduce Staff

docs.abstract: The paper, struggling to overcome the decline in advertising, has reduced the size of its newsroom staff by more than 200 people over the last three years.
docs.snippet: The paper, struggling to overcome the decline in advertising, has reduced the size of its newsroom staff by more than 200 people over the last three years.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9:44 a.m. | Updated The Washington Post announced a new round of buyouts on Wednesday, the latest in a series of staff reductions that have decreased the size of its newsroom by more than 200 people over the last three years.

headline.main: Washington Post Will Further Reduce Staff

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing criticism from religious-affiliated institutions, the Obama administration promised on Tuesday to explore ways to make a new health insurance requirement more flexible.

headline.seo: Obama Addresses Ire on Health Insurance Contraception Rule
headline.main: Obama Tries to Ease Ire on Contraception Rule
headline.print_headline: Obama Tries to Ease Ire on Contraception Rule

docs.abstract: Obama administration is seeking to ease mounting objections to a new rule that would require health insurance plans, including those offered by Catholic universities and charities, to offer birth control to women free of charge; administration officials promise to explore ways to make it more palatable to religious-affiliated institutions, reacting to vocal opposition from religious leaders and an escalating political fight.
docs.snippet: Facing criticism from religious-affiliated institutions, the Obama administration promised on Tuesday to explore ways to make a new health insurance requirement more flexible.

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

docs.lead_paragraph: As time runs short for a bipartisan Congressional negotiating group, there is talk of another short-term extension for payroll tax cuts and jobless benefits.

headline.seo: In Congress, Talks on Payroll Tax Cut Extension at Impasse
headline.main: Talks Stall on How to Pay for Extending Payroll Tax Cut
headline.print_headline: Talks Stall on How to Pay for Extending Payroll Tax Cut

docs.abstract: Bipartisan Congressional negotiating committee clashes over how to pay for another short-term extension of payroll tax cuts and jobless benefits; Senate Democrats suggest they will come up with their own bill to get the matter resolved.
docs.snippet: As time runs short for a bipartisan Congressional negotiating group, there is talk of another short-term extension for payroll tax cuts and jobless benefits.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and JONATHAN WEISMAN
